background: Childhood adversity (CA) is a major risk factor for stress-related psychiatric and medical disorders, and epigenetic mechanisms, such as DNA methylation, may be involved.
hypotheses: The variability of DNA methylation is best explained by the combined effects of genotype and CA, rather than CA alone.
The combined effects of genotype and CA on DNA methylation variability are consistent across different ages and tissues.
major_findings: For the majority of CpG sites, DNA methylation variability was best explained by additive or interactive effects of genotype and CA, not CA alone.

Across five cohorts spanning a wide age range, 1672 CpG sites showed consistent best-fitting models, with G × CA interactions explaining most variance. These sites mapped to genes enriched in brain-specific transcripts and functions related to development and synaptic function.
methods: DNA methylation analysis (Illumina Infinium HumanMethylation450K BeadChips and Infinium MethylationEPIC BeadChip)
Genotyping (Illumina OmniQuad, HumanOmniExpress BeadChips, Illumina GSA-24 v2.0 BeadChips, Illumina 610k chips)
Statistical analysis (linear regression, variance explained, enrichment analysis)
